description: From Medieval Latin tractio, from Latin tractus, perfect passive participle of verb trahere (“pull”), + noun of action suffix -io (genitive -ionis).

entries.meaning: The act of pulling something along a surface using motive power.
The condition of being so pulled.
The pulling power of an engine or animal.
The adhesive friction of a wheel etc on a surface.

definitionGroups.group: (usually after forms of gain, get or have) Progress in or momentum toward achieving a goal, especially in gaining support, recognition, or popularity.

entries.meaning: (business) The extent of adoption of a new product or service, typically measured in number of customers or level of revenue achieved.
(medicine) A mechanically applied sustained pull, especially to a limb.
(transport) Collectively, the locomotives of a railroad, especially electric locomotives.

verbs.description: traction (third-person singular simple present tractions, present participle tractioning, simple past and past participle tractioned)

entries.meaning: (medicine, transitive) To apply a sustained pull to (a limb, etc.).
